Switch Statements

The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

Thom Crescenzi

The Good

  • Compacts your code
    • 
          int x=1;
          switch (x){
            case 1:
             system.out.println("It's 1!");
            case 2:
              system.out.println("It's 2!");
            default
              system.out.println("I only like 1 and 2");
          }

The Good

  • Can be very appropriate and readable
    • 
          char underCase='c';
          switch (underCase){
            case 'a':
             return 'A';
            case 'b':
              return 'B';
            //and so on
          }

The Bad

  • Doesn't actually reduce code size in a meanginful way
    • 
          int x=1;
          switch (x){
            case 1:
             system.out.println("It's 1!");
            case 2:
              system.out.println("It's 2!");
            default
              system.out.println("I only like 1 and 2");
          }
        
    
          int x=1;
          if(x==1){
            system.out.println("It's 1!");
          }else if(x==2){
            system.out.println("It's 2!");
          }else{
            system.out.println("I only like 1 and 2");
          }

actually the switch is a line longer

The Ugly

  • Up until now my examples have all had a huge error. Anyone catch it?
    • 
          int x=1;
          switch (x){
            case 1:
             system.out.println("It's 1!");
            case 2:
              system.out.println("It's 2!");
            default
              system.out.println("I only like 1 and 2");
          }
        
    
          int x=1;
          switch (x){
            case 1:
             system.out.println("It's 1!");break;
            case 2:
              system.out.println("It's 2!");break;
            default
              system.out.println("I only like 1 and 2");
          }

break; sucks

Ugly Breaks

  • Sometimes you want it other times you don't
    • 
          char underCase='c';
          switch (underCase){
            case 'a':
             return 'A';
            case 'b':
              return 'B';
            //and so on
          }

    Actually works as intended

switch is enticing

but is dangerous and not necessary

What's Better

  • If Statements
    • 
          if($a123 > 3){
            $a123=0;
          }
          if($a123 == 0){
          }

    Not that if statement



  • With proper use and clear variable names ifs can be pretty
  • Or even better use pattern matching or guards

the end
